article.title: Identification of a novel Golgi-localized putative glycosyltransferase protein in Arabidopsis thaliana
funding: Grants-in-Aid for Scientific Research from the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology
Sasakawa Scientific Research Grant from the Japan Science Society
Basis for Supporting Innovative Drug Discovery and Life Science Research (BINDS)
article.abstract: SNAREs play an important role in the process of membrane trafficking. In the present research, we investigated subcellular localization of an uncharacterized Arabidopsis thaliana protein reported to interact with a trans-Golgi network-localized Qa-SNARE, SYNTAXIN OF PLANTS 43.

sections.introduction: An efficient and well-organized intracellular transport system is a basic requirement for life to exist, as many components necessary for metabolic processes, that take place inside or outside of a eukaryotic cell, are produced and subsequently modified in different cell compartments.
sections.methods: For colocalization observations, Arabidopsis plants were grown in growth chamber, in 22°C in long-day light (16 h/8 h, L/D) conditions on MS medium w/vitamins (Duchefa Biochemie), containing 0.3% gellan gum (Wako) and 2% sucrose.
sections.results: AtGTLP is predicted to be a membrane-anchored protein comprising of 568 residues.
sections.discussion: In our subcellular localization study, we found that AtGTLP colocalized well with the trans-Golgi marker, ST, as well as with the Golgi marker, GOS12.

article.insights_summary: We identified a novel Golgi-localized putative glycosyltransferase protein in Arabidopsis thaliana, which colocalized well with the trans-Golgi marker, ST, as well as with the Golgi marker, GOS12.
article.acknowledgments: We thank K. Schumacher (Heidelberg University, Germany) for sharing materials.
